At the facility, the areas are divided as followings:
Phase 1 Area:
The LPG (Propane & Butane) facility consists of a total of 25 bullet tanks, and one Sphere. 
The propane bullets facilities for Phase 1 consist of 10 bullet tanks located at north area of the plant. The total storage capacity of the bullets is 20,000 BBLS.
The LPG Facility has the capacity of trucks being loaded from the bullet tanks or sphere at a rate of 200 to 2,271.74 liters per minute.
The butane bullets facilities consist of 15 bullet tanks, and one Sphere, located at south area of the plant. Also, the 10 bullet tanks located at north area of the plant facilities can be used for butane storage. The total storage capacity of the bullets is 36,899 BBLS. 
Each bullet is connected to the dock's 10-inch pipeline for filling purpose and connected to butane pumps' 10-inch suction header. The sphere is connected also to the dock's 10-inch pipeline for filling purpose and connected to butane bullets filling pipeline for filling the butane bullets purpose. 
Butane is transferred from the bullets to the truck loading terminal and, eventually, to tank trucks for distribution to customers.
Butane and propane transfer rate from barges to bullet tanks or sphere is 1,000 gal/min.
Propane transfer rate from bullet to ship is 2,100 gal/min.

Phase 2A:
The storage capacity for Phase 2A consisted of eight (8) bullets tanks located at the Southwest of the plant. The total storage capacity of phase 2A tanks is 16,000 bbls. The pipelines connected the Phase 2A storage tanks to the facilities such as dock and truck loading terminal.

Executive Summary-amended
                            Puma Energy Caribe, LLC
                           Puma Bayamon LPG Terminal
                              Risk Management Plan


Puma Energy Caribe, LLC (Puma) is currently performing butane and propane storage and truck loading activities at its terminal site located at State Road #28, km. 0.2, Bayamon, Puerto Rico.  The Terminal is using the Guaynabo Puma dock facilities to receive and ship product. Puma is required to comply with United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68 because the facility stores propane and butane on-site in quantities exceeding the rule threshold quantity for these substances.  The following executive summary is provided in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.155.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Puma is committed to operating and maintaining its butane and propane operations (generically referred to as liquefied petroleum gas or LPG) in a safe and responsible manner.  Puma has developed and implemented accidental release prevention and emergency response provisions at the facility, including those required under the USEPA RMP rule and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The facility is also subject to other emergency plan regulations such as those under the Oil Pollution Act (OPA) of 1990, state Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (ECPRA), and United States Coast Guard (USCG) rules.

Description of Facility and Regulated Substances
Puma operates a petroleum product terminal located in Bayamon, Puerto Rico, which handles butane and propane, which are regulated flammable substances under RMP regulations.  Puma's butane and propane terminal loading activities consist of:

Planned Changes to improve Safety
PUMA continually strives to improve process safety. The facility's butane and propane processes are built and designed in accordance with recognized safety industry standards and/or government requirements. PUMA expects that on-going programs such as process hazard analyses, compliance audits, and incident investigations will result in continual improvements to process safety.

Pre-Startup Review - Reviews are conducted for new or significantly modified processes to ensure the facilities and processes are adequate and safe for operation.
Compliance Audits - Periodic audits are conducted at least every three years to verify compliance with RMP requirements, with prompt and appropriate responses following any finding and deficiencies identified during the audit.
Incident Investigation - Incidents that result in or could reasonably result in catastrophic releases of butane or propane will be investigated within 48 hours of an incident, and findings will be addressed promptly.
Employee Participation - The facility has a program for involvement of employees in conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other process safety management elements.
Hot Work Permit - Permits will be required and issued for hot work operations conducted on or near a butane or propane process.
Contractor Safety - The facility has a program to evaluate contractors and ensure that contractors are properly trained, informed of all hazards, and performing work in a safe manner.

Five-year Accident History
PUMA Energy Caribe, LLC, purchased the Facility on May 11, 2011, which includes the LPG (Propane & Butane) facilities divided as Phase 1 and Phase 2 (ABCD) areas. The LPG Phase 1 consists of 25 bullet tanks, and one (1) Sphere. Phase 2 (ABCD) consists of additional tanks and lines. No record from previous owner operation has been recorded of an RMP regulated chemical. Since the acquisition until present, one (1) accident occurred on September 29, 2016, where for 15 minutes an approximate 26,899 lbs propane release was detected at the vessel/bullet Tk-859.

Phases 2C and 2D Areas:
The capacity for Phases 2C and 2D consisted of eighteen (18) bullets tanks located at the Northeast of the plant. The total storage capacity of phases 2C and 2D tanks is 36,000 bbls. The added pipelines will connect the new storage tanks to the existing facilities such as dock and truck loading terminal. 
 
Phase 2B Area: 
The storage capacity for Phase 2B consisted of seven (7) bullets tanks located at the North and Northwest of the plant. The total storage capacity of phase 2B tanks is 12,000 bbls. The pipelines connected the Phase 2B storage tanks to facilities such as dock and truck loading terminal.

General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The facility's general accident prevention program consists of compliance with USEPA's RMP and OSHA's PSM regulations. Key elements include the following:
Process Safety Information - Information regarding butane and propane hazards, process technology, and process equipment is complied, updated, and made available to operating personnel.
Process Hazard Analysis - Analyses are conducted every five years with the objective of identifying, evaluating, and controlling the process hazards, and findings and recommendations are promptly addressed.
Operating Procedures - Procedures are developed and maintained up to date to provide instructions for safe operations of process equipment during various phases of operation.
Training - Initial and recurring training is provided to all employees involved in operating a regulated process.
Mechanical Integrity - Procedures are developed and implemented to maintain the on-going integrity of vessels, process piping, transfer hoses, and other process equipment. These include procedures for maintenance, training of maintenance employees, and inspection and testing.
